pros: Very nice place to work. Not the highest pay (it's higher ed...), but the working environment was very pleasant. HR folks are outstanding!

review_title: Great place to work and study
pros: I was a student worker and I believe Emmanuel had a great balance between your obligations as a student and an on-campus employee. They made clear that you were a student first and that your studying was important.
cons: Occasionally, on-campus work would interfere with off-campus events or could overlap with studies, meaning you had to find coverage which could be difficult.

review_title: I was never officially furloughed/fired/laid off
job_title: Customer Service & Marketing Manager in Boston, MA
pros:
- Slow-moving environment. This is a pro for some people.
- No high stakes - whether your work is mediocre or exceeds expectations, you will be treated the same
- For the most part, an intellectual environment where educated conversations are welcome
- Work-life balance is surprisingly nice
- Most of the entry-level associates within this organization are incredibly friendly and would be great to read a book with or something.
cons:
- Abysmal handling of the pandemic — as a student worker, I was never officially furloughed/fired/laid off. I was simply ghosted by my bosses.
- Slow-moving environment. This is a con for me. Nothing fundamentally changes, despite systemic racism and LGBTQ+ discrimination within the ranks of the college.
- Purposefully bureaucratic. Many people wouldn't work in colleges if they weren't a necessary element forged by bureaucracy. For example, facilities team members existing solely for the purpose of approving/denying requests, or every director needing administrative assistants to fulfill rigorous internal protocols.
- Seemingly everyone here is an "associate director", yet they can't precisely tell you what they do. This contributes to a lot of redundancy and "too many chefs ruining the stew."
- A rigidly old-fashioned hierarchical environment that strongly values ego. My roughly six different bosses did NOT accept feedback. They also did not allow coordination with other internal stakeholders without their explicit, unanimous approval. This lead to most meetings being cold, passive-aggressive, and redundant.
- The pay is a joke

pros: A small college with big ideas. It's nice to work in a place that isn't afraid to take chances, it means two days are never the same. Also, it has to compete with some big names in Boston. I feel as though I have learned a lot in my time there - I'm encouraged to learn new skills and take on new responsibility and am rewarded for it.
cons: The pay is not wonderful, but it is higher education (and nonprofit). Also, I feel that some offices hire unqualified people (hoping they'll learn?) and it becomes the burden of coworkers and other offices to pick up the slack when balls are dropped. In that equation, some people are paid for working very little and others are paid the same for doing more than one job.

pros:
I worked at Emmanuel a few years back in a temp-to-hire position in the admissions office.

Great atmosphere with great fellow employees.  Lots of camaraderie, with lots of staff eating lunch together in the dining hall each day (fine to bring your own lunch in).  Very friendly and supportive deans.  Set hours on my team, able to leave on time each day.

Best perk for me was being able to take graduate classes for free in the evenings.  I'm sure there were limitations on number per term, etc., but they had a great graduate program in Leadership at the time that I took advantage of with great professors.
cons: Because Emmanuel is a Catholic school, I believe their health plan did not cover certain procedures on religious grounds.

pros: People here are really, really  nice, and overall, very dedicated and hardworking.  Everyone is very focused on serving the mission of educating our students.  I have worked at numerous higher ed institutions (and private sector) and this place hands-down has the least office politics and gossip.  benefits are generous, including a 4-day work week in summer.
cons: It's a small liberal arts college, so funds can be tight.  Salaries are fair, but there's some pressure to keep staffing quite lean.

pros: Emmanuel college is a liberal arts school located in the heart of Fenway. I had the pleasure of working with all different types of students and people. Emmanuel is a friendly environment where the people you work with become like family due to thee size.
cons: Emmanuel is one of those places where some people are there simply because they have never left. Emmanuel may need to become more up and coming and implement some changes to some of their buildings.

pros: Emmanuel College is an amazing place to work. The community atmosphere is the biggest draw for both students and staff/faculty.
cons: There are two types of employees at Emmanuel. Those who are in it for the long run, and those who use it as a career builder. Lots of employees have been at Emmanuel for a long time, but we lose a lot of good employees who are just here to gain experience at a great institution and move on.

pros: The Jean Yawkey Center is good for community links, flexibility, easy going team, perfect for college students looking for easy money.
cons: The Jean Yakwey Center is bad for responsibility, overkill on projects, too stressful for such an easy job. hours can be sparse and it can be hard to fit it into your schedule.
